intro: Acacia luteola, commonly known as the yellow acacia, is a shrub native to southern Africa. It features small, yellow flowers that bloom in dense, globular clusters, attracting various pollinators. The plant has phyllodes, which are flattened leaf stalks that function as leaves, reducing water loss in arid environments. Its root system is deep and extensive, allowing it to access water from deeper soil layers. Acacia luteola is often used in traditional medicine for its purported health benefits.

Its genus is Acacia, a large group of shrubs and trees known for their acicular leaves and often symbiotic relationships with nitrogen-fixing bacteria. Its species is Acacia luteola, a specific type of acacia known for its yellow flowers and adapted to arid environments.
distribution_native_art_desc: Acacia luteola is primarily native to Western Australia. It is commonly found in the sandy soils of the southwestern region of the state. This plant thrives in arid and semi-arid environments, often growing in open woodlands and heathlands. It is well adapted to the dry climate and can tolerate poor soil conditions. Acacia luteola plays an important ecological role in its native habitat.
distribution_introduced_art_desc: Acacia luteola was mainly introduced to New Zealand as an ornamental plant due to its attractive yellow flowers and drought-resistant characteristics. It has since become naturalized in various regions, particularly in the North Island, where it thrives in disturbed soils and open habitats. Despite its aesthetic appeal, it has raised concerns due to its potential to invade native ecosystems and compete with indigenous plant species.
